This is a very good and accurate analysis of the Republican Party long term strategy. But what about the Democratic Party and its strategy for the 21st century? Other than bashing the Republicans as the bad guys, which in many instances they are, Democrats have failed to present a clear and detailed plan of how the party and its candidates would tackle the myriad of challenges which this nation faces and will face in the face of a fast changing world.

Just stating over and over that the Republicans are obstructionist is not going to resolve that problem and the prospect of Mr. Obama spending the next four years decrying the fact that nothing can be done because the party of "no" will not vote for it is a frightening prospect.

We should be careful about assuming that the GOP's strategy of riling up an extremist base is short-sighted.

Yes, demographics are trending away from the GOP and in favor of a more inclusive and diverse society. But the GOP realizes they only need to get unfettered control of DC for one or two more Presidential terms to cement in radical changes to our government and democracy that will take decades or more to change.

The GOP is seeking to do this in five ways:

1. Eliminating campaign finance laws through Citizens United, etc. so that money has an even tighter grip on our elections and policy making

2. Voter suppression efforts - such as voter ID laws and restrictions on voter registration drives - which disproportionately impact Democratic-leaning constituencies

3. Appointing young movement conservatives to lifetime judicial posts on the Supreme Court and lower courts

4. Running up deficits in order to create a fiscal "crisis" that "requires" dismantling programs like Medicare and deprives future Presidents and Congresses from having resources available to address societal issues

5. Undermining the infrastructure of the Democratic Party by, for example, weakening unions.

We progressives need to not assume that the GOP is short-sighted, and instead understand the GOP is doing whatever it takes to win in 2012 so that they can cement in the steps listed above.

There is an important second part to the quote in which the London Telegraph (the original source for the story!) reports the adviser as saying, "The White House didn’t fully appreciate the shared history we have”.

This thinly coded statement appeals to a culture-based, race-based imperialism, a doctrine of Western cultural hegemony thoroughly discredited and globally reputed and no doubt shows an appalling ignorance.

South Carolina, the wealthiest colony, had an African majority from 1705 forward, reaching 90 % in the coastal parishes and 70 % in Charleston. The language (called Gullah), culture (ways of thinking, natural use of local plants for medicine, cooking (egg plant was called Guinea squash), music, song, story telling, and ethics) were shared by English and African immigrants, and many whites value these African traditions today (bow tied lawyers still speak and sing Gullah and eat traditional foods like perlo (a rice dish). The wealth of the colony, the source of the American dream, depended on African rice growing skills.

If the message was intended for voters in the US, England must feel exploited that Romney, whose grandfather lived in Mexico, would center his approach on questioning the affinity of a President whose grandfather from Kansas fought in WW2 to protect the liberty of England.

Neal, Target stores in Missoula (don't know if it's in other cities as well) take glass for recycling.  Collection containers are just inside the store.  They don't advertise this fact.  (My wife and I just returned from a trip to Montana, and, while there, found this out while we were trying to get rid of our glass food and beverage bottles.)

We have glass recycling courtesy of Target in Kalispell. Check your local one because I know you are either in Mizzou or Bozo.  Happy to hear a brewery is reusing bottles, we were just in Europe and remarked on that very thing.

I live in one of the few liberal towns in MT.  A local brewery that's been here for 25 yrs just installed a bottle washer and takes any beer bottle that works, not all do.  The owner (moved here from Germany) figures in a couple years all his competitors will be paying for all his glass.  And is hoping someone in the US will start making bottles that can be re-used 30 times like they do in Germany, rather than 5 or 6 times.  Our sewage plant has a composting company next door that takes the solids, and the plant has installed an anaerobic digester that someday may even export electricity.  And MT doesn't even have re-cycling laws anywhere close to Oregon.  There is no glass re-cycling anywhere, just paper and aluminum cans.
